241.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

242.speaker: CLINTON:
242.text: We have to make up for lost times, because I want to invest in you. I want to invest in hard-working families. And I think it's been unfortunate, but it's happened, that since the Great Recession, the gains have all gone to the top. And we need to reverse that.
242.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

243.speaker: CLINTON:
243.text: People like Donald, who paid zero in taxes, zero for our vets, zero for our military, zero for health and education, that is wrong.
243.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

244.speaker: COOPER:
244.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

245.speaker: CLINTON:
245.text: And we're going to make sure that nobody, no corporation, and no individual can get away without paying his fair share to support our country.
245.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

246.speaker: COOPER:
246.text: Thank you. I want to give you—Mr. Trump, I want to give you the chance to respond. I just wanted to tell our viewers what she's referring to. In the last month, taxes were the number-one issue on Facebook for the first time in the campaign. The New York Times published three pages of your 1995 tax returns. They show you claimed a $916 million loss, which means you could have avoided paying personal federal income taxes for years. You've said you pay state taxes, employee taxes, real estate taxes, property taxes. You have not answered, though, a simple question. Did you use that $916 million loss to avoid paying personal federal income taxes for years?
246.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

247.speaker: TRUMP:
247.text: Of course I do. Of course I do. And so do all of her donors, or most of her donors. I know many of her donors. Her donors took massive tax write-offs.
247.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

248.speaker: COOPER:
248.text: So have you paid personal federal income tax?
248.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

249.speaker: TRUMP:
249.text: A lot of my—excuse me, Anderson—a lot of my write- off was depreciation and other things that Hillary as a senator allowed. And she'll always allow it, because the people that give her all this money, they want it. That's why.
249.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

250.speaker: TRUMP:
250.text: See, I understand the tax code better than anybody that's ever run for president. Hillary Clinton—and it's extremely complex—Hillary Clinton has friends that want all of these provisions, including they want the carried interest provision, which is very important to Wall Street people. But they really want the carried interest provision, which I believe Hillary's leaving. Very interesting why she's leaving carried interest.
250.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

251.speaker: TRUMP:
251.text: But I will tell you that, number one, I pay tremendous numbers of taxes. I absolutely used it. And so did Warren Buffett and so did George Soros and so did many of the other people that Hillary is getting money from. Now, I won't mention their names, because they're rich, but they're not famous. So we won't make them famous.
251.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

252.speaker: COOPER:
252.text: So can you—can you say how many years you have avoided paying personal federal income taxes?
252.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

253.speaker: TRUMP:
253.text: No, but I pay tax, and I pay federal tax, too. But I have a write-off, a lot of it's depreciation, which is a wonderful charge. I love depreciation. You know, she's given it to us.
253.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

254.speaker: TRUMP:
254.text: Hey, if she had a problem—for 30 years she's been doing this, Anderson. I say it all the time. She talks about health care. Why didn't she do something about it? She talks about taxes. Why didn't she do something about it? She doesn't do anything about anything other than talk. With her, it's all talk and no action.
254.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

255.speaker: COOPER:
255.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

256.speaker: TRUMP:
256.text: And, again, Bernie Sanders, it's really bad judgment. She has made bad judgment not only on taxes. She's made bad judgments on Libya, on Syria, on Iraq. I mean, her and Obama, whether you like it or not, the way they got out of Iraq, the vacuum they've left, that's why ISIS formed in the first place. They started from that little area, and now they're in 32 different nations, Hillary. Congratulations. Great job.
256.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

257.speaker: COOPER:
257.text: Secretary—I want you to be able to respond, Secretary Clinton.
257.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

258.speaker: CLINTON:
258.text: Well, here we go again. I've been in favor of getting rid of carried interest for years, starting when I was a senator from New York. But that's not the point here.
258.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

259.speaker: TRUMP:
259.text: Why didn't you do it? Why didn't you do it?
259.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

260.speaker: COOPER:
260.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

261.speaker: CLINTON:
261.text: Because I was a senator with a Republican president.
261.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

262.speaker: TRUMP:
262.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

263.speaker: CLINTON:
263.text: I will be the president and we will get it done. That's exactly right.
263.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

264.speaker: TRUMP:
264.text: You could have done it, if you were an effective—if you were an effective senator, you could have done it. If you were an effective senator, you could have done it. But you were not an effective senator.
264.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

265.speaker: COOPER:
265.text: Please allow her to respond. She didn't interrupt you.
265.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

266.speaker: CLINTON:
266.text: You know, under our Constitution, presidents have something called veto power. Look, he has now said repeatedly, "30 years this and 30 years that." So let me talk about my 30 years in public service. I'm very glad to do so.
266.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

267.speaker: CLINTON:
267.text: Eight million kids every year have health insurance, because when I was first lady I worked with Democrats and Republicans to create the Children's Health Insurance Program. Hundreds of thousands of kids now have a chance to be adopted because I worked to change our adoption and foster care system. After 9/11, I went to work with Republican mayor, governor and president to rebuild New York and to get health care for our first responders who were suffering because they had run toward danger and gotten sickened by it. Hundreds of thousands of National Guard and Reserve members have health care because of work that I did, and children have safer medicines because I was able to pass a law that required the dosing to be more carefully done.
267.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

268.speaker: CLINTON:
268.text: When I was secretary of state, I went around the world advocating for our country, but also advocating for women's rights, to make sure that women had a decent chance to have a better life and negotiated a treaty with Russia to lower nuclear weapons. Four hundred pieces of legislation have my name on it as a sponsor or cosponsor when I was a senator for eight years.
268.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

269.speaker: CLINTON:
269.text: I worked very hard and was very proud to be re-elected in New York by an even bigger margin than I had been elected the first time. And as president, I will take that work, that bipartisan work, that finding common ground, because you have to be able to get along with people to get things done in Washington.
269.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

270.speaker: COOPER:
270.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

271.speaker: CLINTON:
271.text: I've proven that I can, and for 30 years, I've produced results for people.
271.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

272.speaker: COOPER:
272.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

273.speaker: RADDATZ:
273.text: We're going to move on to Syria. Both of you have mentioned that.
273.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

274.speaker: TRUMP:
274.text: She said a lot of things that were false. I mean, I think we should be allowed to maybe...
274.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

275.speaker: RADDATZ:
275.text: No, we can—no, Mr. Trump, we're going to go on. This is about the audience.
275.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

276.speaker: TRUMP:
276.text: Excuse me. Because she has been a disaster as a senator. A disaster.
276.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

277.speaker: RADDATZ:
277.text: Mr. Trump, we're going to move on. The heart-breaking video of a 5-year-old Syrian boy named Omran sitting in an ambulance after being pulled from the rubble after an air strike in Aleppo focused the world's attention on the horrors of the war in Syria, with 136 million views on Facebook alone.
277.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

278.speaker: RADDATZ:
278.text: But there are much worse images coming out of Aleppo every day now, where in the past few weeks alone, 400 people have been killed, at least 100 of them children. Just days ago, the State Department called for a war crimes investigation of the Syrian regime of Bashar al-Assad and its ally, Russia, for their bombardment of Aleppo.
278.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

279.speaker: RADDATZ:
279.text: So this next question comes through social media through Facebook. Diane from Pennsylvania asks, if you were president, what would you do about Syria and the humanitarian crisis in Aleppo? Isn't it a lot like the Holocaust when the U.S. waited too long before we helped? Secretary Clinton, we will begin with your two minutes.
279.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

280.speaker: CLINTON:
280.text: Well, the situation in Syria is catastrophic. And every day that goes by, we see the results of the regime by Assad in partnership with the Iranians on the ground, the Russians in the air, bombarding places, in particular Aleppo, where there are hundreds of thousands of people, probably about 250,000 still left. And there is a determined effort by the Russian air force to destroy Aleppo in order to eliminate the last of the Syrian rebels who are really holding out against the Assad regime.
280.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

281.speaker: CLINTON:
281.text: Russia hasn't paid any attention to ISIS. They're interested in keeping Assad in power. So I, when I was secretary of state, advocated and I advocate today a no-fly zone and safe zones. We need some leverage with the Russians, because they are not going to come to the negotiating table for a diplomatic resolution, unless there is some leverage over them. And we have to work more closely with our partners and allies on the ground.
281.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

282.speaker: CLINTON:
282.text: But I want to emphasize that what is at stake here is the ambitions and the aggressiveness of Russia. Russia has decided that it's all in, in Syria. And they've also decided who they want to see become president of the United States, too, and it's not me. I've stood up to Russia. I've taken on Putin and others, and I would do that as president.
282.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

283.speaker: CLINTON:
283.text: I think wherever we can cooperate with Russia, that's fine. And I did as secretary of state. That's how we got a treaty reducing nuclear weapons. It's how we got the sanctions on Iran that put a lid on the Iranian nuclear program without firing a single shot. So I would go to the negotiating table with more leverage than we have now. But I do support the effort to investigate for crimes, war crimes committed by the Syrians and the Russians and try to hold them accountable.
283.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

284.speaker: RADDATZ:
284.text: Thank you, Secretary Clinton. Mr. Trump?
284.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

285.speaker: TRUMP:
285.text: First of all, she was there as secretary of state with the so-called line in the sand, which...
285.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

286.speaker: CLINTON:
286.text: No, I wasn't. I was gone. I hate to interrupt you, but at some point...
286.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

287.speaker: TRUMP:
287.text: OK. But you were in contact—excuse me. You were...
287.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

288.speaker: CLINTON:
288.text: At some point, we need to do some fact-checking here.
288.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

289.speaker: TRUMP:
289.text: You were in total contact with the White House, and perhaps, sadly, Obama probably still listened to you. I don't think he would be listening to you very much anymore.
289.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

290.speaker: TRUMP:
290.text: Obama draws the line in the sand. It was laughed at all over the world what happened.
290.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

291.speaker: TRUMP:
291.text: Now, with that being said, she talks tough against Russia. But our nuclear program has fallen way behind, and they've gone wild with their nuclear program. Not good. Our government shouldn't have allowed that to happen. Russia is new in terms of nuclear. We are old. We're tired. We're exhausted in terms of nuclear. A very bad thing.
291.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

292.speaker: TRUMP:
292.text: Now, she talks tough, she talks really tough against Putin and against Assad. She talks in favor of the rebels. She doesn't even know who the rebels are. You know, every time we take rebels, whether it's in Iraq or anywhere else, we're arming people. And you know what happens? They end up being worse than the people.
292.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

293.speaker: TRUMP:
293.text: Look at what she did in Libya with Gadhafi. Gadhafi's out. It's a mess. And, by the way, ISIS has a good chunk of their oil. I'm sure you probably have heard that. It was a disaster. Because the fact is, almost everything she's done in foreign policy has been a mistake and it's been a disaster.
293.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

294.speaker: TRUMP:
294.text: But if you look at Russia, just take a look at Russia, and look at what they did this week, where I agree, she wasn't there, but possibly she's consulted. We sign a peace treaty. Everyone's all excited. Well, what Russia did with Assad and, by the way, with Iran, who you made very powerful with the dumbest deal perhaps I've ever seen in the history of deal-making, the Iran deal, with the $150 billion, with the $1.7 billion in cash, which is enough to fill up this room.
294.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

295.speaker: TRUMP:
295.text: But look at that deal. Iran now and Russia are now against us. So she wants to fight. She wants to fight for rebels. There's only one problem. You don't even know who the rebels are. So what's the purpose?
295.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

296.speaker: RADDATZ:
296.text: Mr. Trump, Mr. Trump, your two minutes is up.
296.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

297.speaker: TRUMP:
297.text: And one thing I have to say.
297.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

298.speaker: RADDATZ:
298.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

299.speaker: TRUMP:
299.text: I don't like Assad at all, but Assad is killing ISIS. Russia is killing ISIS. And Iran is killing ISIS. And those three have now lined up because of our weak foreign policy.
299.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

300.speaker: RADDATZ:
300.text: Mr. Trump, let me repeat the question. If you were president...[
300.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

301.speaker: TRUMP:
301.text: OK. He and I haven't spoken, and I disagree. I disagree.
301.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

302.speaker: RADDATZ:
302.text: You disagree with your running mate?
302.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

303.speaker: TRUMP:
303.text: I think you have to knock out ISIS. Right now, Syria is fighting ISIS. We have people that want to fight both at the same time. But Syria is no longer Syria. Syria is Russia and it's Iran, who she made strong and Kerry and Obama made into a very powerful nation and a very rich nation, very, very quickly, very, very quickly.
303.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

304.speaker: TRUMP:
304.text: I believe we have to get ISIS. We have to worry about ISIS before we can get too much more involved. She had a chance to do something with Syria. They had a chance. And that was the line. And she didn't.
304.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

305.speaker: RADDATZ:
305.text: What do you think will happen if Aleppo falls?
305.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

306.speaker: TRUMP:
306.text: I think Aleppo is a disaster, humanitarian-wise.
306.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

307.speaker: RADDATZ:
307.text: What do you think will happen if it falls?
307.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

308.speaker: TRUMP:
308.text: I think that it basically has fallen. OK? It basically has fallen. Let me tell you something. You take a look at Mosul. The biggest problem I have with the stupidity of our foreign policy, we have Mosul. They think a lot of the ISIS leaders are in Mosul. So we have announcements coming out of Washington and coming out of Iraq, we will be attacking Mosul in three weeks or four weeks.
308.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

309.speaker: TRUMP:
309.text: Well, all of these bad leaders from ISIS are leaving Mosul. Why can't they do it quietly? Why can't they do the attack, make it a sneak attack, and after the attack is made, inform the American public that we've knocked out the leaders, we've had a tremendous success? People leave. Why do they have to say we're going to be attacking Mosul within the next four to six weeks, which is what they're saying? How stupid is our country?
309.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

310.speaker: RADDATZ:
310.text: There are sometimes reasons the military does that. Psychological warfare.
310.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

311.speaker: TRUMP:
311.text: I can't think of any. I can't think of any. And I'm pretty good at it.
311.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

312.speaker: RADDATZ:
312.text: It might be to help get civilians out.
312.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

313.speaker: TRUMP:
313.text: And we have General Flynn. And we have—look, I have 200 generals and admirals who endorsed me. I have 21 Congressional Medal of Honor recipients who endorsed me. We talk about it all the time. They understand, why can't they do something secretively, where they go in and they knock out the leadership? How—why would these people stay there? I've been reading now...
313.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

314.speaker: RADDATZ:
314.text: Tell me what your strategy is.
314.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

315.speaker: TRUMP:
315.text: ... for weeks—I've been reading now for weeks about Mosul, that it's the harbor of where—you know, between Raqqa and Mosul, this is where they think the ISIS leaders are. Why would they be saying—they're not staying there anymore. They're gone. Because everybody's talking about how Iraq, which is us with our leadership, goes in to fight Mosul.
315.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

316.speaker: TRUMP:
316.text: Now, with these 200 admirals and generals, they can't believe it. All I say is this. General George Patton, General Douglas MacArthur are spinning in their grave at the stupidity of what we're doing in the Middle East.
316.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

317.speaker: RADDATZ:
317.text: I'm going to go to Secretary Clinton. Secretary Clinton, you want Assad to go. You advocated arming rebels, but it looks like that may be too late for Aleppo. You talk about diplomatic efforts. Those have failed. Cease-fires have failed. Would you introduce the threat of U.S. military force beyond a no-fly zone against the Assad regime to back up diplomacy?
317.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

318.speaker: CLINTON:
318.text: I would not use American ground forces in Syria. I think that would be a very serious mistake. I don't think American troops should be holding territory, which is what they would have to do as an occupying force. I don't think that is a smart strategy.
318.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

319.speaker: CLINTON:
319.text: I do think the use of special forces, which we're using, the use of enablers and trainers in Iraq, which has had some positive effects, are very much in our interests, and so I do support what is happening, but let me just...
319.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

320.speaker: RADDATZ:
320.text: But what would you do differently than President Obama is doing?
320.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

321.speaker: CLINTON:
321.text: Well, Martha, I hope that by the time I—if I'm fortunate...
321.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

322.speaker: TRUMP:
322.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

323.speaker: CLINTON:
323.text: I hope by the time I am president that we will have pushed ISIS out of Iraq. I do think that there is a good chance that we can take Mosul. And, you know, Donald says he knows more about ISIS than the generals. No, he doesn't.
323.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

324.speaker: CLINTON:
324.text: There are a lot of very important planning going on, and some of it is to signal to the Sunnis in the area, as well as Kurdish Peshmerga fighters, that we all need to be in this. And that takes a lot of planning and preparation.
324.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

325.speaker: CLINTON:
325.text: I would go after Baghdadi. I would specifically target Baghdadi, because I think our targeting of Al Qaida leaders—and I was involved in a lot of those operations, highly classified ones—made a difference. So I think that could help.
325.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

326.speaker: CLINTON:
326.text: I would also consider arming the Kurds. The Kurds have been our best partners in Syria, as well as Iraq. And I know there's a lot of concern about that in some circles, but I think they should have the equipment they need so that Kurdish and Arab fighters on the ground are the principal way that we take Raqqa after pushing ISIS out of Iraq.
326.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

327.speaker: RADDATZ:
327.text: Thank you very much. We're going to move on...
327.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

328.speaker: TRUMP:
328.text: You know what's funny? She went over a minute over, and you don't stop her. When I go one second over, it's like a big deal.
328.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

329.speaker: RADDATZ:
329.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

330.speaker: TRUMP:
330.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

331.speaker: COOPER:
331.text: We've got a question over here from James Carter. Mr. Carter?
331.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

332.speaker: QUESTION:
332.text: My question is, do you believe you can be a devoted president to all the people in the United States?
332.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

333.speaker: COOPER:
333.text: That question begins for Mr. Trump.
333.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

334.speaker: TRUMP:
334.text: Absolutely. I mean, she calls our people deplorable, a large group, and irredeemable. I will be a president for all of our people. And I'll be a president that will turn our inner cities around and will give strength to people and will give economics to people and will bring jobs back.
334.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

335.speaker: TRUMP:
335.text: Because NAFTA, signed by her husband, is perhaps the greatest disaster trade deal in the history of the world. Not in this country. It stripped us of manufacturing jobs. We lost our jobs. We lost our money. We lost our plants. It is a disaster. And now she wants to sign TPP, even though she says now she's for it. She called it the gold standard. And by the way, at the last debate, she lied, because it turned out that she did say the gold standard and she said she didn't say it. They actually said that she lied. OK? And she lied. But she's lied about a lot of things.
335.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

336.speaker: TRUMP:
336.text: I would be a president for all of the people, African-Americans, the inner cities. Devastating what's happening to our inner cities. She's been talking about it for years. As usual, she talks about it, nothing happens. She doesn't get it done.
336.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

337.speaker: TRUMP:
337.text: Same with the Latino Americans, the Hispanic Americans. The same exact thing. They talk, they don't get it done. You go into the inner cities and—you see it's 45 percent poverty. African- Americans now 45 percent poverty in the inner cities. The education is a disaster. Jobs are essentially nonexistent.
337.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

338.speaker: TRUMP:
338.text: I mean, it's—you know, and I've been saying at big speeches where I have 20,000 and 30,000 people, what do you have to lose? It can't get any worse. And she's been talking about the inner cities for 25 years. Nothing's going to ever happen.
338.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

339.speaker: TRUMP:
339.text: Let me tell you, if she's president of the United States, nothing's going to happen. It's just going to be talk. And all of her friends, the taxes we were talking about, and I would just get it by osmosis. She's not doing any me favors. But by doing all the others' favors, she's doing me favors.
339.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

340.speaker: COOPER:
340.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

341.speaker: TRUMP:
341.text: But I will tell you, she's all talk. It doesn't get done. All you have to do is take a look at her Senate run. Take a look at upstate New York.
341.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

342.speaker: COOPER:
342.text: Your two minutes is up. Secretary Clinton, two minutes?
342.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

343.speaker: TRUMP:
343.text: It turned out to be a disaster.
343.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

344.speaker: COOPER:
344.text: You have two minutes, Secretary Clinton.
344.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

345.speaker: CLINTON:
345.text: Well, 67 percent of the people voted to re-elect me when I ran for my second term, and I was very proud and very humbled by that.
345.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

346.speaker: CLINTON:
346.text: Mr. Carter, I have tried my entire life to do what I can to support children and families. You know, right out of law school, I went to work for the Children's Defense Fund. And Donald talks a lot about, you know, the 30 years I've been in public service. I'm proud of that. You know, I started off as a young lawyer working against discrimination against African-American children in schools and in the criminal justice system. I worked to make sure that kids with disabilities could get a public education, something that I care very much about. I have worked with Latinos—one of my first jobs in politics was down in south Texas registering Latino citizens to be able to vote. So I have a deep devotion, to use your absolutely correct word, to making sure that an every American feels like he or she has a place in our country.
346.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

347.speaker: CLINTON:
347.text: And I think when you look at the letters that I get, a lot of people are worried that maybe they wouldn't have a place in Donald Trump's America. They write me, and one woman wrote me about her son, Felix. She adopted him from Ethiopia when he was a toddler. He's 10 years old now. This is the only one country he's ever known. And he listens to Donald on TV and he said to his mother one day, will he send me back to Ethiopia if he gets elected?
347.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

348.speaker: CLINTON:
348.text: You know, children listen to what is being said. To go back to the very, very first question. And there's a lot of fear—in fact, teachers and parents are calling it the Trump effect. Bullying is up. A lot of people are feeling, you know, uneasy. A lot of kids are expressing their concerns.
348.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

349.speaker: CLINTON:
349.text: So, first and foremost, I will do everything I can to reach out to everybody.
349.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

350.speaker: COOPER:
350.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

351.speaker: CLINTON:
351.text: Democrats, Republicans, independents, people across our country. If you don't vote for me, I still want to be your president.
351.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

352.speaker: COOPER:
352.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

353.speaker: CLINTON:
353.text: I want to be the best president I can be for every American.
353.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

354.speaker: COOPER:
354.text: Secretary Clinton, your two minutes is up. I want to follow up on something that Donald Trump actually said to you, a comment you made last month. You said that half of Donald Trump's supporters are, quote, "deplorables, racist, sexist, homophobic, xenophobic, Islamophobic." You later said you regretted saying half. You didn't express regret for using the term "deplorables." To Mr. Carter's question, how can you unite a country if you've written off tens of millions of Americans?
354.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

355.speaker: CLINTON:
355.text: Well, within hours I said that I was sorry about the way I talked about that, because my argument is not with his supporters. It's with him and with the hateful and divisive campaign that he has run, and the inciting of violence at his rallies, and the very brutal kinds of comments about not just women, but all Americans, all kinds of Americans.
355.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

356.speaker: CLINTON:
356.text: And what he has said about African-Americans and Latinos, about Muslims, about POWs, about immigrants, about people with disabilities, he's never apologized for. And so I do think that a lot of the tone and tenor that he has said—I'm proud of the campaign that Bernie Sanders and I ran. We ran a campaign based on issues, not insults. And he is supporting me 100 percent.
356.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

357.speaker: COOPER:
357.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

358.speaker: CLINTON:
358.text: Because we talked about what we wanted to do. We might have had some differences, and we had a lot of debates...
358.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

359.speaker: COOPER:
359.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

360.speaker: TRUMP:
360.text: ... but we believed that we could make the country better. And I was proud of that.
360.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

361.speaker: COOPER:
361.text: I want to give you a minute to respond.
361.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

362.speaker: TRUMP:
362.text: We have a divided nation. We have a very divided nation. You look at Charlotte. You look at Baltimore. You look at the violence that's taking place in the inner cities, Chicago, you take a look at Washington, D.C.
362.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

363.speaker: TRUMP:
363.text: We have an increase in murder within our cities, the biggest in 45 years. We have a divided nation, because people like her—and believe me, she has tremendous hate in her heart. And when she said deplorables, she meant it. And when she said irredeemable, they're irredeemable, you didn't mention that, but when she said they're irredeemable, to me that might have been even worse.
363.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

364.speaker: COOPER:
364.text: She said some of them are irredeemable.
364.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

365.speaker: TRUMP:
365.text: She's got tremendous—she's got tremendous hatred. And this country cannot take another four years of Barack Obama, and that's what you're getting with her.
365.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

366.speaker: COOPER:
366.text: Mr. Trump, let me follow up with you. In 2008, you wrote in one of your books that the most important characteristic of a good leader is discipline. You said, if a leader doesn't have it, quote, "he or she won't be one for very long." In the days after the first debate, you sent out a series of tweets from 3 a.m. to 5 a.m., including one that told people to check out a sex tape. Is that the discipline of a good leader?
366.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

367.speaker: TRUMP:
367.text: No, there wasn't check out a sex tape. It was just take a look at the person that she built up to be this wonderful Girl Scout who was no Girl Scout.
367.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

368.speaker: COOPER:
368.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

369.speaker: TRUMP:
369.text: By the way, just so you understand, when she said 3 o'clock in the morning, take a look at Benghazi. She said who is going to answer the call at 3 o'clock in the morning? Guess what? She didn't answer it, because when Ambassador Stevens...
369.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

370.speaker: COOPER:
370.text: The question is, is that the discipline of a good leader?
370.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

371.speaker: TRUMP:
371.text: ... 600—wait a minute, Anderson, 600 times. Well, she said she was awake at 3 o'clock in the morning, and she also sent a tweet out at 3 o'clock in the morning, but I won't even mention that. But she said she'll be awake. Who's going—the famous thing, we're going to answer our call at 3 o'clock in the morning. Guess what happened? Ambassador Stevens—Ambassador Stevens sent 600 requests for help. And the only one she talked to was Sidney Blumenthal, who's her friend and not a good guy, by the way. So, you know, she shouldn't be talking about that.
371.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

372.speaker: TRUMP:
372.text: Now, tweeting happens to be a modern day form of communication. I mean, you can like it or not like it. I have, between Facebook and Twitter, I have almost 25 million people. It's a very effective way of communication. So you can put it down, but it is a very effective form of communication. I'm not un-proud of it, to be honest with you.
372.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

373.speaker: COOPER:
373.text: Secretary Clinton, does Mr. Trump have the discipline to be a good leader?
373.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

374.speaker: CLINTON:
374.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

375.speaker: TRUMP:
375.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

376.speaker: CLINTON:
376.text: Well, it's not only my opinion. It's the opinion of many others, national security experts, Republicans, former Republican members of Congress. But it's in part because those of us who have had the great privilege of seeing this job up close and know how difficult it is, and it's not just because I watched my husband take a $300 billion deficit and turn it into a $200 billion surplus, and 23 million new jobs were created, and incomes went up for everybody. Everybody. African-American incomes went up 33 percent.
376.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

377.speaker: CLINTON:
377.text: And it's not just because I worked with George W. Bush after 9/11, and I was very proud that when I told him what the city needed, what we needed to recover, he said you've got it, and he never wavered. He stuck with me.
377.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

378.speaker: CLINTON:
378.text: And I have worked and I admire President Obama. He inherited the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression. That was a terrible time for our country.
378.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

379.speaker: COOPER:
379.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

380.speaker: CLINTON:
380.text: Nine million people lost their jobs.
380.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

381.speaker: RADDATZ:
381.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

382.speaker: CLINTON:
382.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

383.speaker: RADDATZ:
383.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

384.speaker: CLINTON:
384.text: And $13 trillion in family wealth was wiped out. We are back on the right track. He would send us back into recession with his tax plans that benefit the wealthiest of Americans.
384.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

385.speaker: RADDATZ:
385.text: Secretary Clinton, we are moving to an audience question. We're almost out of time. We have another...
385.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

386.speaker: TRUMP:
386.text: We have the slowest growth since 1929.
386.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

387.speaker: RADDATZ:
387.text: We're moving to an audience question.
387.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

388.speaker: TRUMP:
388.text: It is—our country has the slowest growth and jobs are a disaster.
388.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

389.speaker: RADDATZ:
389.text: Mr. Trump, Secretary Clinton, we want to get to the audience. Thank you very much both of you. [
389.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

390.speaker: RADDATZ:
390.text: We have another audience question. Beth Miller has a question for both candidates.
390.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

391.speaker: QUESTION:
391.text: Good evening. Perhaps the most important aspect of this election is the Supreme Court justice. What would you prioritize as the most important aspect of selecting a Supreme Court justice?
391.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

392.speaker: RADDATZ:
392.text: We begin with your two minutes, Secretary Clinton.
392.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

393.speaker: CLINTON:
393.text: Thank you. Well, you're right. This is one of the most important issues in this election. I want to appoint Supreme Court justices who understand the way the world really works, who have real-life experience, who have not just been in a big law firm and maybe clerked for a judge and then gotten on the bench, but, you know, maybe they tried some more cases, they actually understand what people are up against.
393.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

394.speaker: CLINTON:
394.text: Because I think the current court has gone in the wrong direction. And so I would want to see the Supreme Court reverse Citizens United and get dark, unaccountable money out of our politics. Donald doesn't agree with that.
394.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

395.speaker: CLINTON:
395.text: I would like the Supreme Court to understand that voting rights are still a big problem in many parts of our country, that we don't always do everything we can to make it possible for people of color and older people and young people to be able to exercise their franchise. I want a Supreme Court that will stick with Roe v. Wade and a woman's right to choose, and I want a Supreme Court that will stick with marriage equality.
395.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

396.speaker: CLINTON:
396.text: Now, Donald has put forth the names of some people that he would consider. And among the ones that he has suggested are people who would reverse Roe v. Wade and reverse marriage equality. I think that would be a terrible mistake and would take us backwards.
396.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

397.speaker: CLINTON:
397.text: I want a Supreme Court that doesn't always side with corporate interests. I want a Supreme Court that understands because you're wealthy and you can give more money to something doesn't mean you have any more rights or should have any more rights than anybody else.
397.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

398.speaker: CLINTON:
398.text: So I have very clear views about what I want to see to kind of change the balance on the Supreme Court. And I regret deeply that the Senate has not done its job and they have not permitted a vote on the person that President Obama, a highly qualified person, they've not given him a vote to be able to be have the full complement of nine Supreme Court justices. I think that was a dereliction of duty.
398.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

399.speaker: CLINTON:
399.text: I hope that they will see their way to doing it, but if I am so fortunate enough as to be president, I will immediately move to make sure that we fill that, we have nine justices that get to work on behalf of our people.
399.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

400.speaker: RADDATZ:
400.text: Thank you, Secretary Clinton. Thank you. You're out of time. Mr. Trump?
400.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

401.speaker: TRUMP:
401.text: Justice Scalia, great judge, died recently. And we have a vacancy. I am looking to appoint judges very much in the mold of Justice Scalia. I'm looking for judges—and I've actually picked 20 of them so that people would see, highly respected, highly thought of, and actually very beautifully reviewed by just about everybody.
401.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

402.speaker: TRUMP:
402.text: But people that will respect the Constitution of the United States. And I think that this is so important. Also, the Second Amendment, which is totally under siege by people like Hillary Clinton. They'll respect the Second Amendment and what it stands for, what it represents. So important to me.
402.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

403.speaker: TRUMP:
403.text: Now, Hillary mentioned something about contributions just so you understand. So I will have in my race more than $100 million put in—of my money, meaning I'm not taking all of this big money from all of these different corporations like she's doing. What I ask is this.
403.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

404.speaker: TRUMP:
404.text: So I'm putting in more than—by the time it's finished, I'll have more than $100 million invested. Pretty much self-funding money. We're raising money for the Republican Party, and we're doing tremendously on the small donations, $61 average or so.
404.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

405.speaker: TRUMP:
405.text: I ask Hillary, why doesn't—she made $250 million by being in office. She used the power of her office to make a lot of money. Why isn't she funding, not for $100 million, but why don't you put $10 million or $20 million or $25 million or $30 million into your own campaign?
405.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

406.speaker: TRUMP:
406.text: It's $30 million less for special interests that will tell you exactly what to do and it would really, I think, be a nice sign to the American public. Why aren't you putting some money in? You have a lot of it. You've made a lot of it because of the fact that you've been in office. Made a lot of it while you were secretary of state, actually. So why aren't you putting money into your own campaign? I'm just curious.
406.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

407.speaker: CLINTON:
407.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

408.speaker: RADDATZ:
408.text: Thank you very much. We're going to get on to one more question.
408.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

409.speaker: CLINTON:
409.text: The question was about the Supreme Court. And I just want to quickly say, I respect the Second Amendment. But I believe there should be comprehensive background checks, and we should close the gun show loophole, and close the online loophole.
409.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

410.speaker: COOPER:
410.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

411.speaker: RADDATZ:
411.text: We have—we have one more question, Mrs. Clinton.
411.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

412.speaker: CLINTON:
412.text: We have to save as many lives as we possibly can.
412.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

413.speaker: COOPER:
413.text: We have one more question from Ken Bone about energy policy. Ken?
413.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

414.speaker: QUESTION:
414.text: What steps will your energy policy take to meet our energy needs, while at the same time remaining environmentally friendly and minimizing job loss for fossil power plant workers?
414.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

415.speaker: COOPER:
415.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

416.speaker: TRUMP:
416.text: Absolutely. I think it's such a great question, because energy is under siege by the Obama administration. Under absolutely siege. The EPA, Environmental Protection Agency, is killing these energy companies. And foreign companies are now coming in buying our—buying so many of our different plants and then re-jiggering the plant so that they can take care of their oil.
416.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

417.speaker: TRUMP:
417.text: We are killing—absolutely killing our energy business in this country. Now, I'm all for alternative forms of energy, including wind, including solar, et cetera. But we need much more than wind and solar.
417.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

418.speaker: TRUMP:
418.text: And you look at our miners. Hillary Clinton wants to put all the miners out of business. There is a thing called clean coal. Coal will last for 1,000 years in this country. Now we have natural gas and so many other things because of technology. We have unbelievable—we have found over the last seven years, we have found tremendous wealth right under our feet. So good. Especially when you have $20 trillion in debt.
418.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

419.speaker: TRUMP:
419.text: I will bring our energy companies back. They'll be able to compete. They'll make money. They'll pay off our national debt. They'll pay off our tremendous budget deficits, which are tremendous. But we are putting our energy companies out of business. We have to bring back our workers.
419.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

420.speaker: TRUMP:
420.text: You take a look at what's happening to steel and the cost of steel and China dumping vast amounts of steel all over the United States, which essentially is killing our steelworkers and our steel companies. We have to guard our energy companies. We have to make it possible.
420.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

421.speaker: TRUMP:
421.text: The EPA is so restrictive that they are putting our energy companies out of business. And all you have to do is go to a great place like West Virginia or places like Ohio, which is phenomenal, or places like Pennsylvania and you see what they're doing to the people, miners and others in the energy business. It's a disgrace.
421.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

422.speaker: COOPER:
422.text: Your time is up. Thank you.
422.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

423.speaker: TRUMP:
423.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

424.speaker: COOPER:
424.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

425.speaker: CLINTON:
425.text: And actually—well, that was very interesting. First of all, China is illegally dumping steel in the United States and Donald Trump is buying it to build his buildings, putting steelworkers and American steel plants out of business. That's something that I fought against as a senator and that I would have a trade prosecutor to make sure that we don't get taken advantage of by China on steel or anything else.
425.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

426.speaker: CLINTON:
426.text: You know, because it sounds like you're in the business or you're aware of people in the business—you know that we are now for the first time ever energy-independent. We are not dependent upon the Middle East. But the Middle East still controls a lot of the prices. So the price of oil has been way down. And that has had a damaging effect on a lot of the oil companies, right? We are, however, producing a lot of natural gas, which serves as a bridge to more renewable fuels. And I think that's an important transition.
426.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

427.speaker: CLINTON:
427.text: We've got to remain energy-independent. It gives us much more power and freedom than to be worried about what goes on in the Middle East. We have enough worries over there without having to worry about that.
427.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

428.speaker: CLINTON:
428.text: So I have a comprehensive energy policy, but it really does include fighting climate change, because I think that is a serious problem. And I support moving toward more clean, renewable energy as quickly as we can, because I think we can be the 21st century clean energy superpower and create millions of new jobs and businesses.
428.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

429.speaker: CLINTON:
429.text: But I also want to be sure that we don't leave people behind. That's why I'm the only candidate from the very beginning of this campaign who had a plan to help us revitalize coal country, because those coal miners and their fathers and their grandfathers, they dug that coal out. A lot of them lost their lives. They were injured, but they turned the lights on and they powered their factories. I don't want to walk away from them. So we've got to do something for them.
429.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

430.speaker: COOPER:
430.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

431.speaker: CLINTON:
431.text: But the price of coal is down worldwide. So we have to look at this comprehensively.
431.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

432.speaker: COOPER:
432.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

433.speaker: CLINTON:
433.text: And that's exactly what I have proposed. I hope you will go to HillaryClinton.com and look at my entire policy.
433.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

434.speaker: COOPER:
434.text: Time is up. We have time for one more...
434.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

435.speaker: RADDATZ:
435.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

436.speaker: COOPER:
436.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

437.speaker: RADDATZ:
437.text: We've sneaked in one more question, and it comes from Karl Becker.
437.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

438.speaker: QUESTION:
438.text: Good evening. My question to both of you is, regardless of the current rhetoric, would either of you name one positive thing that you respect in one another? [
438.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

439.speaker: RADDATZ:
439.text: Mr. Trump, would you like to go first?
439.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

440.speaker: CLINTON:
440.text: Well, I certainly will, because I think that's a very fair and important question. Look, I respect his children. His children are incredibly able and devoted, and I think that says a lot about Donald. I don't agree with nearly anything else he says or does, but I do respect that. And I think that is something that as a mother and a grandmother is very important to me.
440.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

441.speaker: CLINTON:
441.text: So I believe that this election has become in part so—so conflict-oriented, so intense because there's a lot at stake. This is not an ordinary time, and this is not an ordinary election. We are going to be choosing a president who will set policy for not just four or eight years, but because of some of the important decisions we have to make here at home and around the world, from the Supreme Court to energy and so much else, and so there is a lot at stake. It's one of the most consequential elections that we've had.
441.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

442.speaker: CLINTON:
442.text: And that's why I've tried to put forth specific policies and plans, trying to get it off of the personal and put it on to what it is I want to do as president. And that's why I hope people will check on that for themselves so that they can see that, yes, I've spent 30 years, actually maybe a little more, working to help kids and families. And I want to take all that experience to the White House and do that every single day.
442.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

443.speaker: RADDATZ:
443.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

444.speaker: TRUMP:
444.text: Well, I consider her statement about my children to be a very nice compliment. I don't know if it was meant to be a compliment, but it is a great—I'm very proud of my children. And they've done a wonderful job, and they've been wonderful, wonderful kids. So I consider that a compliment.
444.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

445.speaker: TRUMP:
445.text: I will say this about Hillary. She doesn't quit. She doesn't give up. I respect that. I tell it like it is. She's a fighter. I disagree with much of what she's fighting for. I do disagree with her judgment in many cases. But she does fight hard, and she doesn't quit, and she doesn't give up. And I consider that to be a very good trait.
445.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

446.speaker: RADDATZ:
446.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

447.speaker: COOPER:
447.text: We want to thank both the candidates. We want to thank the university here. This concludes the town hall meeting. Our thanks to the candidates, the commission, Washington University, and to everybody who watched.
447.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri

448.speaker: RADDATZ:
448.text: Please tune in on October 19th for the final presidential debate that will take place at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas. Good night, everyone.
448.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri
